facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2293 of 1968 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2293 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated October 9, 1967 of Kerala High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 64 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated  October 9, 1967 of the Kerala High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 64 of 1966.

facts.text: Reference made under S. 26(1) of the Gift Tax Act, 1958, relating to assessment year 1964-65.

anchor.surface_text: from a judgment of the Kerala High Court in a reference made under S. 26  1   of the Gift Tax Act, 1958, hereinafter referred to as the Act, relating to the assessment year 1964-65.

facts.text: Assessee was sole proprietor of business Travancore Timbers and Products at Kottayam.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was the sole proprietor of the business run under the name and style of Travancore Timbers and Products at Kottayam.

facts.text: Proprietary business converted into partnership by deed dated August 1, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: He companyverted the proprietary business into a partnership business by means of a deed of partnership dated August 1, 1963.

facts.text: Partnership consisted of assessee and his two daughters, one married and one unmarried.

anchor.surface_text: The partnership companysisted of the assessee and his two daughters. The capital of the partnership was to be Rs. 4,00,000/-. The assessee companytributed Rs. 3,50,000/

facts.text: Partnership capital Rs. 4,00,000; assessee contributed Rs. 3,50,000, each daughter Rs. 25,000 by transfer from assessee's account.

anchor.surface_text: and each of his two daughters, one of whom was married and the other unmarried, companytributed Rs. 25,000/-. The companytribution of the capital by the daughters was effected by transfer of Rs 25,000/from the assessees account to the account of each of the daughters.

facts.text: All assets of proprietary business transferred to partnership.

anchor.surface_text: All the assets of the proprietary business were transferred to the partnership.

facts.text: Shares in assets: assessee 7/8, each daughter 1/16.

anchor.surface_text: In these assets the assessee and his daughters were entitled to shares in proportion to their share capital. In other words the assessee was entitled to a 7/8 share and each of his daughters to 1/16 share.

facts.text: Profits and losses divided equally among three partners.

anchor.surface_text: The profits and losses of the partnership, business, however, were to be divided in equal shares between all the three partners.

facts.text: Assessee was managing partner.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was the managing partner of the firm.

facts.text: Assessee filed gift tax return for 1964-65 for gift of Rs. 50,000 to daughters.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee filed a return of gift tax for the assessment year 1964-65 in respect of the gift of Rs. 50,000/- in favour of his daughters representing the share capital companytributed by his daughters.

facts.text: Gift Tax Officer held additional gift of 2/3rd goodwill valued at Rs. 1,07,910 apart from Rs. 50,000.

anchor.surface_text: The Gift Tax Officer, however, took the view that in addition to the gift of the aforesaid amount the assessee had gifted 1/3rd portion of the goodwill of his proprietary business to each of his daughters. On the basis of the profits of the earlier years the Gift Tax Officer determined the value of the goodwill at Rs. 1,61,865/- and the value of the 2/3rd share of the goodwill gifted to the daughters at Rs. 1,07,910/- which was added to the amount of Rs. 50,000/- and the gift tax was assessed accordingly.

facts.text: Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee preferred an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Gift Tax which was dismissed.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held goodwill was existing property, gift exempt u/s 5(1)(xiv), only 1/8 share gifted.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal on appeal held  i  the goodwill companystituted an exiting immovable property at the time of-the admission of the assessees daughters into the business  ii  the gift was exempt under s. 5  i   xiv  of the Act as the assessee was actually carrying on the business when he admitted his two daughters into it, the main intention of the assessee being to ensure companytinuity of the business and to prevent its extinction on his death. Such a purpose amounted to business expediency and therefore all the companyditions of s. 5  1   xiv  were satisfied  iii  the goodwill was a capital asset and the assessees daughters had only 1/8 share in the assets of the business.

facts.text: Three questions of law referred by Tribunal at instance of Commissioner of Gift Tax.

anchor.surface_text: The following questions of law were referred by the Tribunal at the instance of the Commissioner of Gift Tax Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the goodwill of the assessees business is an existing property within the meaning of s. 2  xii  of the Gift tax A ct ? Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessee gifted only a 1/8th share in the goodwill of the business to his two daughters or whether he gifted a 2/3rd share ? Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the gift was exempt from assessment under S. 5  1   xiv  of the Gift tax Act ?

facts.text: Kerala High Court answered all questions in favour of assessee against Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered all the questions in favour of the assessee and against the Revenue.

facts.text: Partnership deed recited assessee desirous of introducing major daughters and minor children later.

anchor.surface_text: It was recited, inter alia, that the assessee was desirous of introducing into the business of Travancore Timbers and Products his major daughters and also his minor children as and when they attained majority.

facts.text: Assessee gifted Rs. 25,000 to each major daughter as per deed.

anchor.surface_text: upon the treaty for the introduction of the said partners into the business for the par and for the partnership it was agreed that the first partner  assessee  would gift a sum of Rs. 25,000/- to each of his two major daughters.

facts.text: All properties including goodwill conveyed to partners.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee as beneficial owner companyveyed and assigned unto the partners including himself all these properties including the good-Will of the marks and all rights and privileges belonging thereto.

facts.text: Partnership at will per first schedule.

anchor.surface_text: It was expressly stated in the first schedule which companytained the terms, companyditions and stipulations that the partnership was to be at will.

facts.text: Assessee retained control as managing partner, could sign cheques, borrow etc.

anchor.surface_text: Under clause 10 the assessee was to be the managing partner of the firm. He alone had the power to sign the cheques on account of the partnership in the, name of the firm. He had the power to borrow from Banks and other private parties for the purpose of the business and to execute bands, documents agreements and other activities as might be necessary. There were other provisions also which showed that it was the assessee who retained substantially the companytrol of the running of the business in his own hands.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no gift tax on goodwill.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite obvious that the answer to the first part of the question has to be in the negative and therefore there is numbercessity of answering ,he second part of the question. Question No. 1 also does number arise and need number be answered.

facts.text: Supreme Court held gift of Rs. 50,000 not exempt u/s 5(1)(xiv).

anchor.surface_text: The answer to question No. 3, companysequently, would be in favour of the Revenue and against the assessee so far as that amount is companycerned.

facts.text: Assessee's age below 50 years, no evidence of weak health or daughters' expertise.

anchor.surface_text: particularly when there is numberevidence that he was in a weak state of health, his age being below 50 years. Moreover there is numberhing to show that the daughters had any specialised knowledge or business experience so as to be able to assist in the development or management of the business.

anchor.surface_text: We are wholly unable in these circumstances to accept that the present case is different from Dr. George Kuruvillas. in our judgment there was no cogent material to come to the conclusion that the gift of Rs. 25,000/- to each of the daughters by the assessee was in the course of carrying on the business

holdings.text: No gift tax was payable on the goodwill of the assessee's business

anchor.surface_text: The departmental authorities, in the present case, never treated all the assets and property of the assessee which were transferred to the partnership pertaining to his proprietary business as a gift nor has any suggestion been made before us on behalf of the Revenue that the property and assets valued at Rs. 4,00,000/- were the subject matter of gift. All that the departmental authorities did and. that position continued throughout was that they picked up one of the assets of the assessee's proprietary business, namely, its goodwill and regarded that as the subject of gift having been made to the daughters, who were the other partners of the firm which came into existence by virtue of the deed of partnership. This approach is wholly incomprehensible and no attempt has been made before us to justify it. In our opinion the second question which was referred by the Tribunal should have been framed as follows Whether on the facts and in the circumstances any gift tax was payable on the goodwill of the assessee's business. If the answer be in the affirmative how much share in the goodwill was liable to such tax ? We reframe the question in the above terms. It is quite obvious that the answer to the first part of the question has to be in the negative and therefore there is no necessity of answering ,he second part of the question. Question No. 1 also does not arise and need not be answered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entire proprietary business assets valued at Rs.4 lakhs transferred to partnership proportionate to capital contributions (7/8 assessee, 1/16 each daughter); revenue never taxed full assets as gift; incomprehensible and unjustified to isolate and tax only goodwill share separately as gift

holdings.text: Question No. 1 does not arise and need not be answered

anchor.surface_text: It is quite obvious that the answer to the first part of the question has to be in the negative and therefore there is no necessity of answering ,he second part of the question. Question No. 1 also does not arise and need not be answered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary to decide if goodwill existing property u/s 2(xii) since no gift tax liability on goodwill at all

holdings.text: The second part of reframed Question No. 2 does not arise

anchor.surface_text: It is quite obvious that the answer to the first part of the question has to be in the negative and therefore there is no necessity of answering ,he second part of the question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary to decide quantum of share in goodwill gifted since no gift tax liability on goodwill

holdings.text: The gift of Rs. 50,000 was not exempt under S. 5(1)(xiv) of the Gift Tax Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: Gift not proved made 'in the course of' business (lacks integral connected relation) nor 'bona fide for the purpose' (no commercial expediency: assessee <50 years, healthy, full control as managing partner, daughters inexperienced/no expertise, partnership at will, family benefit intent incl. future minors); applies textual/purposive interpretation of s.5(1)(xiv); follows precedent in Commissioner of Gift Tax v. Dr. George Kuruvilla; distinguishes Tribunal/High Court findings for lack of evidence

precedents.citation: State of Travancore Cochin Others v. Shanmugha Vilas Cashew Nut Factory Others 1

anchor.surface_text: State of Travancore Cochin Others v. Shanmugha Vilas Cashew Nut Factory Others 1 in connection with the language employed in Art. 286 of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: State of Travancore-Cochin v. Shanmugha Vilas Cashew Nut Factory
precedents.cited_proposition: Meaning of 'in the course of': etymologically denotes movement and postulates a connected relation
precedents.cited_holding: The word 'course' etymologically denotes movement from one point to another and the expression 'in the course of' not only implies a period of time during which the movement is in progress but also postulates a connected relation.

precedents.citation: B W. Noble Ltd. v. Mitchell 2

anchor.surface_text: B W. Noble Ltd. v. Mitchell 2 a sum had been paid to a retiring Director in very peculiar circumstances.

precedents.cited_proposition: Payment to retiring director to preserve company status and reputation is for the purpose of the business
precedents.cited_holding: Preservation of the status and dividend earning power of the company was well within the ordinary purpose of the trade, profession or vocation of the company.

anchor.surface_text: Morgan v. Tate Lyle, Ltd. 1 . According to a recent decision of this court in Civil Appeals Nos.

precedents.cited_proposition: Courts refrain from adopting dogmatic line for 'for the purpose of' in connection with trade or business as it depends on facts

precedents.citation: Civil Appeals Nos. 1351-1353, 1897 1241 of 1968 The Commissioner of Income tax, West Bengal Birla Cotton Spinning Weaving Mill,, Ltd. etc. 2

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1351-1353, 1897 1241 of 1968 The Commissioner of Income tax, West Bengal Birla Cotton Spinning Weaving Mill,, Ltd. etc. 2 the expression for the purpose of the business is essentially wider than the expression for the purpose of earning profits.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal v. Birla Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: 'For the purpose of the business' is wider than 'for earning profits'; includes preservation of business, protection of assets
precedents.cited_holding: The expression for the purpose of the business is essentially wider than the expression for the purpose of earning profits. It covers not only the running of the business or its administration but also measures for the preservation of the business, protection of its assets and property.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Gift Tax, Kerala v. Dr. George Kuruvilla 3

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Gift Tax, Kerala v. Dr. George Kuruvilla 3 . There the assessee was a doctor by profession at the time of the gift which he made in favour of his son

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Gift Tax, Kerala v. Dr. George Kuruvilla
precedents.cited_proposition: Gift by doctor to son who joined profession was in the course of and for the purpose of business under s.5(1)(xiv) Gift Tax Act
precedents.cited_holding: The gift had been made in the course of carrying on of the business, profession or vocation within the meaning of s. 5(1)(xiv) of the Act and also for the purpose of such business, profession or vocation.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Gift Tax v. Di-. George Kuruvilla 4

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Gift Tax v. Di-. George Kuruvilla 4 It has been observed that s. 5(1) of the Act does not indicate that a gift made by a person carrying on any business

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Gift Tax v. Dr. George Kuruvilla
precedents.cited_proposition: Gift not exempt under s.5(1)(xiv) Gift Tax Act without evidence it was in the course of and for the purpose of business
precedents.cited_holding: There was no evidence to prove that the gift to the donee was in the course of carrying on the business of the donor and for the purpose of the business.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Gift Tax v. Dr. George Kuruvilla
precedents.cited_proposition: Gift to family members admitting to partnership not in course of or for purpose of business without evidence

anchor.surface_text: The departmental authorities, in the present case, never treated all the assets and property of the assessee which were transferred to the partnership pertaining to his proprietary business as a gift nor has any suggestion been made before us on behalf of the Revenue that the property and assets valued at Rs. 4,00,000/- were the subject matter of gift. All that the departmental authorities did and. that position continued throughout was that they picked up one of the assets of the assessee's proprietary business, namely, its goodwill and regarded that as the subject of gift having been made to the daughters, who were the other partners of the firm which came into existence by virtue of the deed of partnership. This approach is wholly incomprehensible and no attempt has been made before us to justify it. In our opinion the second question which was referred by the Tribunal should have been framed as follows Whether on the facts and in the circumstances any gift tax was payable on the goodwill of the assessee's business. If the answer be in the affirmative how much share in the goodwill was liable to such tax ? We reframe the question in the above terms. It is quite obvious that the answer to the first part of the question has to be in the negative and therefore there is no necessity of answering ,he second part of the question. Question No. 1 also does not arise and need not be answered.

For the reasons given above the answers returned by the High Court are discharged and in their place the question shall stand answered in accordance with this judgment in the following manner Question No. 1 does number arise. Question No. 2 as refr
oved to the satisfaction of the Gift Tax Officer to have been made bona fide for the purpose of such
